name: methyl 2-amino-5-bromobenzoate
Reason: The compound methyl 2-amino-5-bromobenzoate has several functional groups that affect its melting point. The base structure is a benzene ring, which for reference, benzene has a melting point around 5.5 °C. Each functional group will modify this baseline. Firstly, the amine group (-NH2) generally increases the melting point due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, which strengthens intermolecular attractions. This could raise the melting point by approximately +50 °C. The bromine atom adds significant molecular weight and also contributes to dipole-dipole interactions, which can further increase the melting point by roughly +30 °C. The ester group (-CO2CH3) might have a moderate effect on the melting point, possibly increasing it by about +20 °C due to polar interactions. Lastly, the presence of the dipoles and hydrogen bonding interactions in the molecule leads to more Ordered crystal lattice and thus a higher melting point.
Prediction: Estimated increase: Amine group: +50 °C, Bromine atom: +30 °C, Ester group: +20 °C. Base benzene value: 5.5 °C. Prediction: 5.5 (base value) + 50 (amine) + 30 (bromine) + 20 (ester) = 105.5 °C
